38. Where others placed them sideways
and with highlights, he placed his easily
with the heads forward, and never or rarely
highlighted, but blended with deep shadow;
the volumes and foreshortening,
a joy to behold, he achieved without great effort
and better than the rest. Thus, in earlier times,
Nicias of Athens excelled

39. at painting Animals, especially
Dogs, and with great skill made Diana,
As well as Callisto transformed into a Bear,
and Io into a Cow: but I need not
discuss all his other works here,
it is enough for me to affirm
that he painted four-footed Animals
of all kinds wonderfully well.

40. Now we wish to tell further
of two brothers in art, from Rhodes,
Apollonius and Tauriseus, carvers
of Figures, whose leaping Bull is not lost,
but can be seen by everyone in Rome.
There is Dirce.> (whom the Gods later
transformed into a fountain, as the poets told),
also Zetus and Amphion, fine nudes.
left-middleExample of a Bull in Rome, in the Farnese Palace.

41. These Figures, the Bull, and even the cords
which bound Dirce in her shame,
were artfully wrought: sculpted not piece
by piece but, with great intelligence,
from a single block of white Marble.
It was brought by Ship over the Sea,
barren and sandy from Rhodes to Rome,
where it stands, still admired, in a wooden house.

42. O Myron, how could I banish
to dark obscurity your cast bronze Heifer?
About which Greek Poets praise you
with many Epigrams, because above all,
she was so artfully made as to seem alive?
The first of an entire dozen reads thus:
“Herders, drive all your cows elsewhere,
lest this one go to the stable with yours.”
